title: Three-strikes law
summary: In the United States, habitual offender laws[1] (commonly referred to as three-strikes laws) were first implemented on March 7, 1994,[2] and are part of the United States Justice Department's Anti-Violence Strategy.[3][4] These laws require both a severe violent felony and two other previous convictions to serve a mandatory life sentence in prison.[5][6] The purpose of the laws is to drastically increase the punishment of those convicted of more than two serious crimes.[2]
